text: (light music)
- My name is Eric Hudson.
I'm a Cloud Infrastructure Architect
within Global Financial Services

that falls underneath the
Professional Services umbrella.
I have been with AWS over two years now.

Being a COVID hire, I'm just
now coming out of this dream,

and I actually work for
AWS and I do belong here.
I've dealt with the imposter syndrome,

and that new car smell is
starting to wear off of me

to where people are looking
at me as an Amazonian veteran.
I'm involved with the BEN affinity group.

I'm looking to be a mentor, to
actually get out and do more.

There's another group called
A2C, Associate to Contractor,

helping people who want to
get into IT and switch lanes
and change roles from being a brick layer
to building cloud infrastructure.
I think it's just awesome.

And Amazon gives us that
platform and the opportunity
to go out and be a hand up to people
instead of just handouts.

When you get here, you
can actually be yourself.
And one thing I had to deal with
is you don't have to know everything.

Prior to AWS, I was in
roles where I was the guy.
I mean, I knew it all.
Even if I didn't know it all,

the people around me
thought I knew it all.
So when they would come to me,

I had to figure it out because
the bucket stopped with me.

Whereas here, I mean,
everybody's a genius.
So it's okay to humble yourself and say,

"You know, I don't have an
answer for you right now,

but let me do some research
and I'll get back with you."

And there's a channel for
just about everything.
And you ask a question,

and whether it's a new joiner
or it's the product manager
of that service replying to you,
it's just mind-blowingly awesome.

So once you get over that,
hey, Amazon is the real deal.
And you can be yourself,
and there's people to help you out

or answer your questions
if you may have them.
(light music)
